body:
This partially reverts some changes in
ae3eed53d6100598b6d26fe58e3e97541e03f3c1.

Using -S and -B instead of cd:ing causes strange problems for some
users, where the `build` and `.deps` directory aren't created and the
process aborts with `make: cmake: Permission denied`. The cause of this
hasn't been identified yet.

Closes https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/27475.
Closes https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/27488.

comment_regular_data.body: @hsanson I need your help here. I've split up the Makefile changes into granular commits, where each one works for me. Could you bisect and pinpoint which commit that causes a problem for you?

Here are the results of bisect:

```
[~/Apps/neovim]$ git bisect good
4ec34b13a2065db325c86663f967f777a75b9a7b is the first bad commit
commit 4ec34b13a2065db325c86663f967f777a75b9a7b
Author: dundargoc <gocdundar@gmail.com>
Date:   Fri Feb 16 23:14:47 2024 +0100

    build: use -S and -B flags

 Makefile | 8 ++++----
 1 file changed, 4 insertions(+), 4 deletions(-)
```

Dafuq. I thought at first your cmake version was too low but you said in the issue it was cmake version 3.28.1 so that's definitely not it. This is bizarre, I can't come up with a good reason why specifically using `-S` and `-B` from cmake would cause this problem.
@hsanson can you try the latest commit in the PR and see if that works.

@dundargoc unfortunately it does not work:

This is the commit I am building:

```
commit d090a5385a7b473cb3e711fe33f207e3d5fd0ab7 (HEAD -> build/makefile)
Author: dundargoc <gocdundar@gmail.com>
Date:   Sat Feb 17 00:26:35 2024 +0100

    build: remove backslash
```

This is the result:

```[~/Apps/neovim]$ make clean && make distclean && make
test -d build && ninja -C build clean || true
ninja: Entering directory `build'
[0/2] Re-checking globbed directories...
[1/1] Cleaning all built files...
Cleaning... 597 files.
make -C test/old/testdir clean
make[1]: Entering directory '/home/ryujin/Apps/neovim/test/old/testdir'
rm -f -rf *.out *.failed *.res *.rej *.orig *.tlog test_result.log test.log messages starttime test.out X* viminfo test.ok valgrind.* .*.swp .*.swo .gdbinit /home/ryujin/Apps/neovim/test/old/testdir/X-test-tmpdir del ../../../runtime/doc/.*.swp
make[1]: Leaving directory '/home/ryujin/Apps/neovim/test/old/testdir'
make -C runtime/indent clean
make[1]: Entering directory '/home/ryujin/Apps/neovim/runtime/indent'
rm -f testdir/*.fail testdir/*.out
make[1]: Leaving directory '/home/ryujin/Apps/neovim/runtime/indent'
rm -rf .deps build
make clean
make[1]: Entering directory '/home/ryujin/Apps/neovim'
test -d build && ninja -C build clean || true
make -C test/old/testdir clean
make[2]: Entering directory '/home/ryujin/Apps/neovim/test/old/testdir'
rm -f -rf *.out *.failed *.res *.rej *.orig *.tlog test_result.log test.log messages starttime test.out X* viminfo test.ok valgrind.* .*.swp .*.swo .gdbinit /home/ryujin/Apps/neovim/test/old/testdir/X-test-tmpdir del ../../../runtime/doc/.*.swp
make[2]: Leaving directory '/home/ryujin/Apps/neovim/test/old/testdir'
make -C runtime/indent clean
make[2]: Entering directory '/home/ryujin/Apps/neovim/runtime/indent'
rm -f testdir/*.fail testdir/*.out
make[2]: Leaving directory '/home/ryujin/Apps/neovim/runtime/indent'
make[1]: Leaving directory '/home/ryujin/Apps/neovim'
mkdir -p ".deps"
cmake -S /home/ryujin/Apps/neovim//cmake.deps -B .deps -G 'Ninja'   
make: cmake: Permission denied
make: *** [Makefile:96: build/.ran-deps-cmake] Error 127
```

This is my cmake version:


```
[~/Apps/neovim]$ which cmake
/usr/bin/cmake

[~/Apps/neovim]$ cmake --version
cmake version 3.28.1

CMake suite maintained and supported by Kitware (kitware.com/cmake).
```

Reverting the command that does `cd` inside the build and runs cmake from within it instead of using -B and -S flags fixes the problem.

Hi, looks like I'm having the exact same problem on Ubuntu 20.04.

I'm also able to compile up to 3 commits before ✅ [build: remove jank propagation of flags](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/27490/commits/27b78dc4f5216596cb9ca03f1fa52387cad677ff) but not on the latest 2 commits.

```txt
$ cmake --version
cmake version 3.22.1

CMake suite maintained and supported by Kitware (kitware.com/cmake).

$ make --version
GNU Make 4.3
Built for x86_64-pc-linux-gnu
Copyright (C) 1988-2020 Free Software Foundation, Inc.
License GPLv3+: GNU GPL version 3 or later <http://gnu.org/licenses/gpl.html>
This is free software: you are free to change and redistribute it.
There is NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by law.
```

---

Running `cmake -S <path> -B .deps -G 'Ninja'` on the command line (zsh) succeeds to create the folder and works just fine. I've tested `<path>` with 

- `/absolute/path/cmake.deps`
- `/absolute/path//cmake.deps`
- `cmake.deps`

All works fine.

---

I don't get errors on my Arch machine.

Is there anything I can help?

We could revert only the small code section that causes a problem, which is [`4ec34b1` (#27490)](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/27490/commits/4ec34b13a2065db325c86663f967f777a75b9a7b). My only hesitation with that is that we haven't identified what causes this problem, so even if we revert it there's a chance the problem will get re-introduced again.

> Is there anything I can help?

Identify the cause of the problem. I can't recreate this and neither can many others. You have the power to solve this mystery here.

As a last resort we can merge this PR which is good to go. I'd still prefer knowing why this is a problem.

@dundargoc 

When I change that line from `$(CMAKE)` to `/usr/bin/cmake` it works just fine.

So I think it had nothing to do with `cmake` but it is because the name of [this folder](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/tree/master/cmake) is cmake.
That's why `cd <somewhere>` worked but not with the `-S` flag because cwd changes.

As @pysan3 mentions, I can confirm that changing line 12 from:

```
CMAKE ?= $(shell (command -v cmake3 || echo cmake))
```

to 

```
CMAKE ?= $(shell (command -v cmake3 || echo /usr/bin/cmake))
```

fixes the issue.
I'd prefer to see this edge case handled upstream as this is caused by the folder literally named `cmake` in cwd.

Please give me an explanation @clason  

Should I have not devoted my 2 hours to identify the problem? Why am I getting a downvote for what I have done? I tried my best to help you out.

That is welcome, but this is not an edge case to be handled; the folder named `cmake` is literally how CMake works. It's impossible to guard against misspecified environments. I simply disagreed with this one single comment.

So to sum up: master works, the underlying issue has been identified (thanks to your help), and so there's nothing more to be done.

> so there's nothing more to be done.

@clason The code was using `cd` which worked just fine and you guys broke that behavior a couple months ago.

How is adding cwd to PATH a misspecified environment? I haven't seen anything that prevents linux users from doing that.

A sane c project would usually do the `mkdir build; cd $_; cmake ..` trick to avoid this problem, which we are not doing here (and I don't know why).

The commit in December is breaking the old behavior (I believe unconsciously), which IMO should be reverted or at least documented.

I've read through the entire thread and I still have some questions and thoughts. Before I get into the meat of it I want to thank @hsanson and @pysan3 for taking the time to help solve this mystery.

> How is adding cwd to PATH a misspecified environment?

This seems bizarre to me. Having the current directory not only in `PATH` but before other paths sounds like a ticking timebomb. Every project would need to constantly make sure they don't name a directory that coincides with an executable that is needed for the project. I don't see how that's tenable. Unsure if I missed or misunderstood something.

> I haven't seen anything that prevents linux users from doing that.

_Prevents_? No. Linux will happily let you shoot yourself in both feet and then offer to reload your gun for you (you still have hands, after all). But virtually everybody will advise you against it. (Really. Google "linux cwd path" and try to find _one_ page that doesn't mention how bad of an idea that is.)

People are welcome to do it if they know what they're doing; but then they can also be expected to handle any issue arising from it.

OK, so I came to my conclusion that I shouldn't have invested my time, or at least shouldn't have reported my findings here. Thank you guys for your time as well.

It is sad to see this project opinionated in a way that I don't like but thank you for the discussion and I wish you all the best in your future endeavors.

We do appreciate your time; it really did help tracking down this issue. I'm sorry you don't like our decisions on what we can and can't support and hope you'll find a project better aligned with _your_ opinions.

Well, this was an unsatisfactory conclusion :(. In any case, I've never really heard of appending the current working directory to `PATH`, let alone prepending it (which again, sounds like a terrible idea due to the naming conflicts it can cause). I think we should keep it as is until someone provides a reason as to why the current behavior is incorrect.
